Ah, no.

record.text: Having planned readiness exercises for the military, the number one thing I target is the “assumptions”, of what will work. Something always breaks at some point and usually sooner than expected. Whether  it be a weapons system or our ability to communicate in the thrash, nothing ever goes to plan.

… and individuals don’t always behave/perform as expected. 

Tabletop emergency response exercise: “Sheriff” ignores initial steps in response plan; we’re going directly to step X.

Leaves everyone scrabbling to figure out how to implement step X.

Facilitator: You need to do something now.

Exactly! Biggest problem I had was people ignoring human factors and I would intentionally place them into the exercise injects. Too many time exercise players just want to get straight to the action without factoring in something called reality.
I was asked - just once - to be the president in a Naval War College war game. :)
Kewl!! What does the President do in a Naval War College war game??!? Does he get to boss everyone around and blow up imaginary ships??!? Need for details!!  :)

record.text: Oh, sh...

Sounds weird, but have found horror flicks to be a great diversion from the daily chaos machine. Watched A House of Dynamite and couldn't look away. People should see it. Seems pretty realistic. Even with competent, trained, intelligent, thoughtful people at the helm, things are iffy...
Back in 1983, I immediately thought of the SDI program as destabilizing if it was actually implemented as advertised. Now I understand ... and wonder if Reagan, the master pitchman, was told "100%".
Thanks for the gift link and the great article.
i remember the SDI ad during Reagan with the crayon drawing showing the shield evaporating the warheads. Not far off from the actual plans for BMD, evidently.
Ooooof.   As THEY say.

Have to agree that "100% accurate" is propaganda/bluster.

When I was in aerospace working on ballistic missiles, we used to joke that our missile could hit the third button down on Stalin's coat.

They were frightenly accurate but reality does creep in.

author.display_name: James Casey, JD, MPA, MA, CPP

record.text: Fantastic movie! And, no missile defense is 100 percent accurate.

61% is not really that poor of an accuracy rate if you consider that multiple salvos would be fired. 2 shots is 85% accurate. 95% for 3 and 98% for 4. I figure we could get 2 salvos of 2 each fired while the bad guy missile is in flight. I'll take those odds over losing a city.
Which is why it's so dumb they only fired 2 and not 4. But then the movie needed to happen.
No, it's not. There were only 60 GBIs available. They did not know if hundreds more missiles were coming at any moment.

Interesting read but, Tom Clancy may have written a script with a 100% certainty because the superior and better trained American personnel employing said weapon system would never fall short of HIS objective. I've long believed Clancy was a CIA op. No one man could write that many words. Thoughts?

Anyone can write a lot of words if they’re not very good and it’s silly to think that he was some sort of CIA operation when in fact, he couldn’t even get his first book published at a major publisher

I watched it last night. It brought back memories of my school basement, full of canned water and food rations and our exercises at hiding under our desks. Even as kids we knew it was all BS and if a war started we were all toast. Golden dome my ass. Trump is building a 300 million dollar bunker.
What did you think of Jacobsen's book Nuclear War?
I thought it was very readable - I read it in one sitting - but not realistic.
While watching this movie all I could think about was how this administration might handle that situation.  It's a terrifying thought. I hope we never have to find out.
Just saw this movie per your recommendation.  Good movie.
Having lived on Vandenberg AFB in the 90s with minuteman rockets launching regularly. I'm pretty sure it was to improve accuracy because they were never 100%.
I watched it a few days ago, and it scared the bejesus out of this Canadian.
I just finished watching it and I was scared to death thinking about how Trump could never handle a scenario like this.
Seriously, I was just starring at the television after it ended.
Same
I watched all the credits at the end. Couldn’t take my eyes off the screen.
So during the credits is when you heard the three explosions. Bigelow did a terrific job.

Interesting! I didn’t think of it that way. I was thinking it was just a part of the score but it definitely could be interpreted as bombs detonating. I was thinking POTUS would exercise restraint but that’s what makes this film so impactful. It starts conversations.
First time I’ve heard anybody mention that. Good ears.

Former Air Force missileers: Keep Trump away from nukes (October, 2016)
www.airforcetimes.com/news/your-ai...

The missileers delivered a blistering assessment of Trump's temperament and judgment and concluded he should not be the commander-in-chief or "be entrusted with the nuclear launch codes."

record.text: My wife was in disbelief and shocked. I think the story was told really well and should hit home that not every decision and outcome is super easy and barely an inconvenience.
Tom, I was waiting for this. Watched the day it came out and I knew there would be statement’s from “above”.
Enjoyed is probably not the right word, but I was gripped by the movie. I watched it yesterday with my wife. The only gripe I have about it is what happens to the SecDef (won't spoil it).

Yeah, before even knowing for certain what was going to happen.

I mean throughout the whole movie they just assumed it's going to be a nuclear warhead and not a conventional or inert one.
If they say 100%, I’m concerned that 50% may not be possible.  That’s a childish lie.

@radiofreetom.bsky.social In the spirit of military depictions:  I’ve been rewatching Homecoming (Amazon Prime), & I’m curious if you have an opinion on its storytelling — in light of ops against US citizens, it feels prescient even w/its excellent Hitchcockian vibes.

If it’s a 50/50 chance of success then you need 7 launches per incoming object to approach 99% success rate. 

So why only launch 2? We should be building thousands of these things.

“Our system is 100% accurate”

[operational testing demonstrates PK of 78%. Operational doctrine recommends minimum salvo of 3 to ensure hit]

“our system is 100% accurate when we fire enough missiles”
If those numbers mean each interceptor has an 78% chance of success independently, there's still a 0.5% chance of failure with 3 rounds. Low, but not zero.
Scary to think they have to decide how many to fire so they don't exhaust them all...
It's still nonsensical to let an incoming missile through by not launching enough interceptors "just in case there will be more".
Window for interception isn't that long.

I agree with not being able to launch more interceptors once the first pair failed. But they should have fired 4 in the first salvo with that PK.

Of course the movie needed to happen, so I get why they made that choice. I just think the intercept failure could have been scripted a little better.
Article said PK was more like 50-60%. my numbers were just made up. at 50% 4 missiles still only gets you in the 94% range. And, again, there might not even be time to fire 4 in the kill window.

author.display_name: Two all the way, a coffee milk, and a Del's

record.text: It makes sense they had to launch then or not at all but they theoretically could have launched, say, 4 GBIs at once instead of 2 though, right?

you can’t launch them at exactly the same time or they will interfere with each other. 

so you have some minimum time between GBI launches, and some maximum intercept window, and those two things are going to determine how many GBI’s you can try before you’re SOL.

I’m not entirely convinced Trump doesn’t think a “golden dome” isn’t a literal dome that will ensconce the entirety of the mainland United States. He seems to lack the ability to engage in abstract thinking & takes everything literally.
He literally thought the superimposed MS13 label on a guy’s knuckle tattoos were actually on his hand. So, yeah.
Trump it’s dangerous but he’s also extremely stupid.
Why constantly make claims that ate demonstrably false... oh yeah, people are dumb

Imagine you’re a smart, dedicated professional in the MDA who had had a distinguished career…and you have to write memos like this so your president doesn’t blow up. 

Blow up anything, really, to show tough he is.
In the movie, j appreciated the analogy of trying to hit a bullet with a bullet.
Note to Tom – great article, but Fort Greely is in Alaska, and Greeley is in Colorado – i.e. there's a typo.
Will fix

Even if our defenses were "100 percent accurate", at some point you're going to run out of anti-ballistic missiles. Not to mention that our adversaries have multiple delivery systems with capabilities and tactics that we probably aren't fully prepared for.

There was a symbolic reason for Captain Walker taking the toy dinosaur to work.
Extinction.

Some people seem to think you can force something to become true by saying it number of times on TV 📺. 

I don’t think that really works, but that’s just my opinion 🤷‍♂️.
Meh…
Surprised they aren't claiming they are 1,000 percent accurate.
If 100 missiles are launched 🚀 & the intercept is 3 sigma reliable - is that an acceptable error?

record.text:
Finally saw the film last night. Outstanding and riveting, as you say, as fiction- but with just enough confusion and uncertainty (as I witnessed in DC on 9/11) to make it feel nerve racking real.
Amazing cast, writing, and brilliant directing.
In the film, there’s a functioning government and President. Imagine the same scenario with a government like the one we have now.
Coincidentally, I just watched this last night.
One can imagine the scenarios Trump would contemplate when told that the system is 100% accurate.   That's a very dangerous message to convey to a psychopath like Trump.
Well done.   Knowing Trump, his Golden Dome would probably only "protect" the red states.

Just finished "A House of Dynamite"...🚀☢️🚀

Excellent, in Ms. Bigelow's signature understated-but-somehow-still-electric way.

This was as much about people and their complex/captive relationships with the systems of both preventing and executing nuclear war as it was about the systems themselves.

If you want to scare people to death this Halloween, sit them down, make them watch this movie, and ask them afterward how the man who flew off the handle about a TV ad and slapped our closest neighbor and ally up side the head with new tariffs will do in this kind of pressure cooker.

The thing in the end that stayed with me was the last scene, where all the senior advisors had either canceled each other out or crapped out altogether, and the President relied on the judgment of the mid-level naval officer holding the “football”. 1/2
My takeaway was that there is no right answer and you could just as well flip a coin. Seems like that was Bigelow’s point.

record.text:
"but you don’t need to be an expert to know that there’s no such thing as a 100 percent success rate for anything."

Yep, but you probably need some scientific or engineering background to understand that to your bones.

A "House of Dynamite" on Netflix is a very intense film, from 3 POV's, about a ballistic missile launched at the US.

Here's what experts say 'A House of Dynamite' gets wrong (and right) about nuclear war
www.npr.org/2025/10/24/n...

In real life, consider who would decide on a possible response.
… what happened to SALT1?
SALT 1 was signed and went into effect in the 1970s. Do you mean something else?
… no, I meant that are we still limited in the amount of missile “interceptors” that we may deploy or is the definition of ABM different now?
Bush withdrew from the ABM Treaty early in his first term
… that explains it, guess it seemed immaterial to me at the time, thanks!
I thought maybe in effect but ignored due to playing loose with definition of “ABM”
Is that Kathryn Bigelow, and she just happens to look a LOT like Gloria Steinem, or was Steinem secretly involved in ballistic missile defense? Or, both?

Maybe we let Trump have this one. (Or believe it. 🤣🤣)

Otherwise, he’s gonna spend a gazillion dollars on it, because he’s scared to die.

I watched it last night and it was absolutely jarring.  My father was in the senior executive service in the USDA in the 70-80’s in DC.  He told me he was designated in the event of a nuclear war to go to the Greenbrier (I could be mistaken it was over 40 years ago). Nuclear war felt more real.
just like Dan Crenshaw saying the other day that they have 100% certainty that they won't accidentally kill innocent fishermen in the drone strikes. Just begging fate to slap them down.
Then letting a guy go off once of the ships they blew up, said he did nothing wrong

author.display_name: Jenifer 🌻 plants wildflowers for fun and profit

record.text: Nobody who knows anything about real-world engineering will believe that figure, and it just makes them look silly. Wouldn't it be wiser for them to just not say anything publicly about these systems' performance?
Heh. I’ve been in software engineering for nine years. I can assure you that everything worked perfectly in dev.
They should say nothing; if they must lie (and they must) say something believable….87% or something

author.display_name: Jenifer 🌻 plants wildflowers for fun and profit

record.text: (Terrific nail-biter of a movie, by the way. Just got finished watching it a half hour ago.)

Yup.

This is basically a Trumpified MDA talking.

You can tell them I said that, for what it’s worth.
Great article.
I doubt it's improved since I retired from DOD.
Thanks Tom!
Thank you for sharing your article, Tom!
Haven’t seen the movie yet, but your article clearly points to the risks of ignorance, the paucity of critical thinking and the promotion of propaganda in government today

How accurate would you say "House" is with respect to the failed separation of the second GBI? Entirely plausible (see your comments on men and machines!), but how likely? More Hollywood or more reality?
Was the part where they declined to send additional GBI’s after the incoming missile because they needed to save them in case this was a precursor of a bigger launch accurate?

There's a limited engagement window for a particular type of interceptor. You need different systems for exo-atmospheric intercept and terminal phase intercept.

But them launching only two interceptors with 60% probability of intercept was dumb.
Thanks for this insight.

Kim Jong Il said he shot a 38 the first time he played golf, including 11 holes-in-one. That means even HE looked at the situation and thought, “Should I claim 18 holes-in-one? Nah, that would be completely unbelievable.”

Even Israel, with some of the most advanced missile defense systems in the world, couldn’t stop 100% of Iran’s ballistic missiles. The United States, with its far larger territory and far more targets to defend, has even less chance of intercepting an incoming missile.

Having planned readiness exercises for the military, the number one thing I target is the “assumptions”, of what will work. Something always breaks at some point and usually sooner than expected. Whether  it be a weapons system or our ability to communicate in the thrash, nothing ever goes to plan.

In response to "A House of Dynamite," the Pentagon's Missile Defense Agency sent around an internal memo for its leadership with the talking point that US defenses are *100 percent accurate*.

Ah, no.

… and individuals don’t always behave/perform as expected. 

Tabletop emergency response exercise: “Sheriff” ignores initial steps in response plan; we’re going directly to step X.

Leaves everyone scrabbling to figure out how to implement step X.

Exactly! Biggest problem I had was people ignoring human factors and I would intentionally place them into the exercise injects. Too many time exercise players just want to get straight to the action without factoring in something called reality.

record.text:
My wife felt the orchestral “groans” over the opening (and heard occasionally) reminded her a lot of a similar sound in the “Chernobyl” miniseries. And of course SECDEF’s actor played Legasov.

Neither thing really matters in any deep way, though it does add to the sense of dread, by association.

The groans right away made me think the score composer was going for whale sounds because the director said this would be a film about a nuke fired from a sub. The movie never confirmed it but the composer might have.

record.text: If those numbers mean each interceptor has an 78% chance of success independently, there's still a 0.5% chance of failure with 3 rounds. Low, but not zero.
Scary to think they have to decide how many to fire so they don't exhaust them all...
It's still nonsensical to let an incoming missile through by not launching enough interceptors "just in case there will be more".
Window for interception isn't that long.

I agree with not being able to launch more interceptors once the first pair failed. But they should have fired 4 in the first salvo with that PK.

Of course the movie needed to happen, so I get why they made that choice. I just think the intercept failure could have been scripted a little better.
Article said PK was more like 50-60%. my numbers were just made up. at 50% 4 missiles still only gets you in the 94% range. And, again, there might not even be time to fire 4 in the kill window.

author.display_name: Two all the way, a coffee milk, and a Del's

record.text: It makes sense they had to launch then or not at all but they theoretically could have launched, say, 4 GBIs at once instead of 2 though, right?

you can’t launch them at exactly the same time or they will interfere with each other. 

so you have some minimum time between GBI launches, and some maximum intercept window, and those two things are going to determine how many GBI’s you can try before you’re SOL.
